name: Citigroup
title: AI-Driven Enterprise Transformation (Project Bora Bora, -20K Headcount)

classification.classificationRationale: Model 6a (Enterprise-Wide Adoption) confirmed. New data reveals massive scale: 70% AI adoption across 84 countries, 21M+ tool interactions, 175K employees completed mandatory AI training. No CAIO or dedicated AI lab — AI deployed through 'Project Bora Bora' restructuring across all functions. Contextual orientation confirmed: AI automates within existing roles (2.6M customer interactions/month automated, 9% developer productivity gain). Upgraded to Medium confidence based on specific adoption metrics.

description:
Citigroup is executing 'Project Bora Bora' — a multi-year AI-driven restructuring targeting 20,000 role eliminations (~8% of workforce) and $2.5B annualized cost savings by 2026. CEO Jane Fraser frames this as cultural transformation, not just automation: eliminating 'the last vestiges of old, bad habits' and demanding a 'more commercial mindset.'

Scale of adoption is remarkable: 70% AI adoption rate across 84 countries, 21M+ interactions with proprietary AI tools, 175K employees completed mandatory AI training, 2.6M customer interactions automated monthly, 9% developer productivity increase. Over 10K of the 20K target reductions already achieved.

This is enterprise-wide contextual adoption — no CAIO, no dedicated AI lab, AI integrated into existing functions rather than separated structurally.

observableMarkers.resourceAllocation: $2.5B annualized cost savings target from AI and automation

observableMarkers.metrics: -20,000 headcount target (10K+ already cut); 70% AI adoption rate; 21M+ AI tool interactions; 2.6M customer interactions automated/month; 9% developer productivity increase; 175K employees completed AI training

layers.label: Initial Documentation
layers.summary: Citigroup CFO expects -20K headcount via AI automation of middle-office functions. Part of financial services AI restructuring wave.

sources.name: Fortune — Jane Fraser on job cuts and restructuring
sources.notes: 20K headcount reduction target with 10K+ already cut; Fraser frames AI as cultural transformation

sources.name: Citigroup Q4 2025 Earnings Research
sources.notes: $2.5B annualized cost savings target; 70% AI adoption; 21M+ tool interactions; 84 countries

openQuestions: Does Citigroup have a CAIO or centralized AI leadership?
What is the governance structure for AI tool deployment across 84 countries?
How is the $2.5B savings target being measured and tracked?
taxonomyFeedback: Financial services AI restructuring is a sector-level pattern: Citigroup (-20K), Amazon (-16K+), Coca-Cola (phased), all citing AI. The taxonomy could benefit from a 'sector wave' concept.
Citigroup's approach (automate middle office) is different from UBS (appoint CAIO) or JPMorgan (build CoE). Same sector, different organizational responses to AI.

[2026-02] Citigroup is emerging as a potential type specimen for Model 6a at scale. 70% adoption across 84 countries without a CAIO or dedicated AI lab suggests enterprise-wide contextual adoption can achieve massive scale through mandatory training (175K employees) and cultural framing ('judged on results'). Fraser's language about eliminating 'old, bad habits' is interesting — positioning AI adoption as cultural transformation rather than technical change.

[2026-02] The lack of structural AI leadership despite this scale is notable. Compare to JPMorgan (AI CoE), UBS (CAIO). Citigroup achieves similar adoption through Project Bora Bora restructuring + mandatory training. This may be an alternative path to enterprise AI adoption: restructuring-driven rather than structure-driven.
